mapList.access_desc: From Porepunkah, head south at the large round-about onto the Buckland Valley Road for approximately 30 km, where the camping area is located on the left. The Buckland Valley Road is sealed for the first 13km to Buckland Bridge and then unsealed for the remainder. The unsealed section is suitable for two wheel drive access throughout the year, however access to the site may be slippery in wet weather and require a high clearance vehicle.
mapList.name: Shippens

mapList.access_desc: From Myrtleford, travel 31km sth along the Buffalo River Rd, to the Rose River Rd intersection. From here it becomes the Abbeyards Rd which is a gravelled road, suitable for 2WDs, caravans and camper trailers. Travel a further 21km to the campground.
mapList.name: Mclver
mapList.comments: McIver is the fifth campground located at the intersection of the Lake Cobbler tk and Abbeyards Rd and runs alongside the Buffalo River.  It is a small basic bush campground that offers 2 campsites with campfire pits and picnic tables.

mapList.access_desc: From Porepunkah, head south at the large round-about onto the Buckland Valley Road for approximately 32 km, where the camping area is located on the left. The Buckland Valley Road is sealed for the first 13km to Buckland Bridge and then unsealed for the remainder. The unsealed section is suitable for two wheel drive access throughout the year, however access to the site may be slippery in wet weather and require a high clearance vehicle.
mapList.name: Leinster Flat

mapList.access_desc: From Porepunkah, head south at the large round-about onto the Buckland Valley Road for approximately 33 km, where the camping area is located on the left. The Buckland Valley Road is sealed for the first 13km to Buckland Bridge and then unsealed for the remainder. The unsealed section is suitable for two wheel drive access throughout the year, however access to the site may be slippery in wet weather and require a high clearance vehicle.
mapList.name: Good Hope Flat

mapList.access_desc: From Porepunkah, head south at the large round-about onto the Buckland Valley Road for approximately 34 km, where the camping area is located on the left. The Buckland Valley Road is sealed for the first 13km to Buckland Bridge and then unsealed for the remainder. The unsealed section is suitable for two wheel drive access throughout the year, however access to the site may be slippery in wet weather and require a high clearance vehicle.
mapList.name: Headrace Flat

mapList.access_desc: From Porepunkah, head south at the large round-about onto the Buckland Valley Road for approximately 36 km, where the camping area is located on the left. The Buckland Valley Road is sealed for the first 13km to Buckland Bridge and then unsealed for the remainder. The unsealed section is suitable for two wheel drive access throughout the year, however access to the site requires a high clearance vehicle and may be slippery in wet weather.
mapList.name: The Bend

mapList.access_desc: Access is via the Dinner Plain Track which heads south from the Dinner Plain village. this track is subject to a seasonal road closure between mid June and end October.
mapList.name: Black Sallee Picnic Area
mapList.comments: Located on the Long Plain and surrounded by Black Sallee open forest, this picnic area is a scenic spot for a short stay or overnight camp. The site is adjacent to a dam and has an open grassy area suitable for camping.

mapList.access_desc: Travel along the Old Bonang-Bendoc Road, turn into Pretty Gully Track and follow the signs to the tunnel.
mapList.name: Delegate River Tunnel
mapList.comments: A historically significant and well preserved example of alluvial mining used during the Victorian goldrush era.

mapList.access_desc: From Bendoc, travel south down Clarkeville Road before turning left onto Marriot Track where you will proceed a short distance (~1.2km) before arriving at the hut.
mapList.name: Wilsons Hut
mapList.comments: This well restored high country hut is a great place to base yourself for the night while you explore the vast array of history that the Bendoc region has to offer.

mapList.access_desc: The Washington Winch is on Nunniong Road, turn off the Great Alpine Road north of Swifts Creek (via Bindi).
mapList.name: Washington Winch
mapList.comments: A relic of past logging operations the winch is the only steam-powered engine of its kind in Australia. Built in Seattle, USA it was able to haul big logs up steep slopes, carrying them onto the road and load them onto trucks.\r\n

mapList.access_desc: Dingo Hill is at the end of Dingo Hill Track off the Tulloch Ard Rd. Tulloch Ard Road intersects with the Gelantipy Road approx. 5km south of Gelantipy township
mapList.name: Dingo Hill Lookout

mapList.access_desc: Access to Moscow Villa from Swifts Creek is via Nunniong Road and Bentleys Plain Road, from Ensay is via Bentleys Plain Road.
mapList.name: Moscow Villa
mapList.comments: Built in the 1940's by a local Swifts Creek residence and used as a summer residence for him when on Fire Tower Lookout duties. Complete with stone fireplace, wooden floors and tin roof. Outside the hut is room for camping, with picnic tables and a toilet nearby.

mapList.access_desc: Access to the plains is via the township of Ensay and Bentley Plain Rd from the south and via Nunniong Rd and Bentley Plain Rd from the north.
mapList.name: Bentley Plain
mapList.comments: Bentley Plain is a formal camp site situated within the Bentley Plain Natural Features and Scenic Reserve. The site contains a historic forestry hut (refuge only, no fireplace), fire pit, toilets, picnic shelter and a bbq. There is a grassy area within the fence perimeter that is suitable for tents.

mapList.access_desc: Access is via the Birregun Road. from Swifts Creek, head out along the road to Cassilis, then onto the Upper Livingstone Road and Birregun Rd.
mapList.name: Dog'S Grave
mapList.comments: A quiet camping area off the Birregun Road, with a small hut (with pot belly stove), picnic table, fire pit, toilet and room for camping. The site has a historic Dog's Grave.

mapList.access_desc: Travel south from Bendoc down the Clarkeville Road, turn right onto Aspens Battery Track and travel 1.8kms to the mine location.
mapList.name: Jungle King Mine
mapList.comments: Step back in time and witness a fine example of a late 1800's quartz mining shaft which was once the heart of the original Clarkeville settlement.

mapList.close_reason: Unfortunately, Glenmore Huts were destroyed in the Timbarra bushfire in 2019. This site is closed until further notice.
mapList.access_desc: Via Nunnett Rd or via Glenmore Rd. Glenmore Rd has a crossing over the Buchan River which can be deep after flooding.
mapList.name: Glenmore Huts
mapList.comments: Built in 1962, the Glenmore Huts (Logging Camp) were built when the Nunnett area was opened up for alpine logging. Four of the five original huts still remain on site. The huts have local significance as a comparitavely good expression of life in a timber workers camp for this locality. Each hut typically accommodated four timber workers, with the larger one sleeping up to six. The huts were burnt down in the 2019 Nunnett-Timbarra fires. The huts are for refuge only (no fire places) and the site contains an outside fire pit and plenty of room for camping.

mapList.name: Harrison'S Cut
mapList.comments: Harrisons Cut is a 50 metre river diversion which was probably excavated in the early 1880s. The cutting was used to divert the Dargo River to enable the river to be mined for gold. The vehicle track ends at the cutting.\r\n\r\n

mapList.access_desc: From Dargo travel 6km (10 minutes) up the Dargo High Plains Road and turn right onto Upper Dargo Road. Collins Flat is located at the 15km mark.
mapList.name: Collins Flat
mapList.comments: Collins Flat is the last of the main camping areas along the Upper Dargo Road but is just as scenic as the previous sites.

mapList.access_desc: Via the Bonang Highway Goongerah, campground is sign posted onto the Ellery Creek Track.
mapList.name: Goongerah
mapList.comments: Set on the banks of the picturesque Brodribb River, enjoy this tranquil camp set amongst the manna gums, base yourself for a night or a week and enjoy the tall forests that East Gippsland has to offer.

mapList.access_desc: Access is directly off the Timbarra Road, 4WD recommended but not essential.
mapList.name: Timbarra North
mapList.comments: Large camping area located adjacent to the Timbarra River with formal campsites, fire places and toilets.

mapList.access_desc: Travel north from the Princes Highway along the Combienbar Rd turning right onto Staggs Creek Road, travel 5.3kmG before turning left onto Three Sisters Road, continue traveling 13.7kms and then turn right onto Lookout Rd.
mapList.name: Three Sisters Lookout
mapList.comments: Set high above the Combienbar Valley sit back and watch the local peregrine falcons soring above the picturesque scenery.

mapList.access_desc: From Dargo travel 6km (10 minutes) up the Dargo High Plains Road and turn right onto Upper Dargo Road. Black Flat is located at the 10.4km mark of the Upper Dargo Road.
mapList.name: Black Flat
mapList.comments: This campsite has less grassy areas but is well sheltered and provides a great bush setting beside the Dargo River.

mapList.close_reason: Site closed in response to vandalism to the toilet. Alternate camping is available 2.5 km north at Timbarra North.
mapList.access_desc: Access is directly off the Timbarra Rd, south of Buchan. The access track is 4WD only.
mapList.name: Timbarra Central
mapList.comments: Camping area located next to the Timbarra River. The site has formal campsites marked, fire places and a toilet. Access is with 4wd vehicles only.

mapList.access_desc: Access track is located just past the white timber bridge on the Timbarra Road.
mapList.name: Timbarra Picnic Area
mapList.comments: Scenic, shady picnic area located on the banks of the Timbarra River. A less formal camping area is located on the other side of the river, with a toilet and fire places.

mapList.access_desc: From Dargo travel 6km (10 minutes) up the Dargo High Plains Road and turn right onto Upper Dargo Road. Ollies Jump Up is located at the 6.5km mark.
mapList.name: Ollies Jump Up

mapList.access_desc: From Dargo travel 6km (10 minutes) up the Dargo High Plains Road and turn right onto Upper Dargo Road. Jimmy Iverson's is located at the 3.9km mark.
mapList.name: Jimmy Iverson'S
mapList.comments: Another great camping area beside the Dargo River with room for multiple families.

mapList.access_desc: Access is via Errinundra Road, approximately 12 kilometres to the North from the Combienbar/Club Terrace Rd. Access closed to the North at present.
mapList.name: Ada River
mapList.comments: The gateway to the Errinundra Plateau, this site is set amongst our tall East Gippsland forest on the banks of the picturesque Ada River.

mapList.access_desc: From Dargo travel 6km (10 minutes) up the Dargo High Plains Road and turn right onto Upper Dargo Road. Two Mile Creek is located at the 1.9km mark of the road.
mapList.name: Two Mile Creek
mapList.comments: Two Mile Creek is an easily accessible campsite which is located near the junction of Two Mile Creek and the Dargo River. There are a number of camping areas located along the Two Mile Creek, providing a good overnight option for visitors.

mapList.access_desc: From Dargo travel 6km (10 minutes) up the Dargo High Plains Road and turn right onto Upper Dargo Road. Italian Flat is located at the 2.7km mark.
mapList.name: Italian Flat
mapList.comments: This is one of the larger campsites on the Upper Dargo and provides a number of access points down to the Dargo river. Italian has plenty of picnic tables and fire places as well as a toilet.

mapList.access_desc: Turntable Huts are located on the Baldhead Rd, approx. 60 minutes drive from Bairnsdale.
mapList.name: Turntable Huts
mapList.comments: An old settlement built in 1949 for the Forests Commission of Victoria to house the crew engaged in constructing Engineers Road from Bruthen to Mount Baldhead. The huts present a good example of life in a timber workers camp during the post-war era. \r\nThe main hut is bare but can be used for accommodation.

mapList.access_desc: Hut is located at the end of Marthavale Rd off the Baldhead Rd. Approx 1 hour from Bairnsdale, 4WD only access when wet.
mapList.name: Marthavale Hut
mapList.comments: This site contains an historic hut built in the 1950's for timber workers accommodation. The hut is located next to the Nicholson River and has a toilet, picnic table and fire pit. There is plenty of space for camping. The hut is bare but can be used for accommodation - it contains a small fireplace.

mapList.access_desc: Follow the Basin Road east out of Buchan. The turn off to the tower is approx. 1km past the end of the private land.
mapList.name: Mt Mcleod Hut
mapList.comments: Mount McLeod is an old fire lookout location. The site contains the old hut used to house the Fire Lookout Tower workers. The fire tower has been dismantled.

mapList.access_desc: Access is from the Great Alpine Rd, approx. 20 mins drive from Bruthen.
mapList.name: Bark Sheds
mapList.comments: A scenic picnic area located next to the Tambo River. The site has a shelter and a toilet as well as informal camping sites.

mapList.access_desc: Approximately 12 kilometres east of Cann River the rest area is set 200m north of the Princes Hwy.
mapList.name: Drummer Rainforest
mapList.comments: Set within some of East Gippsland's renowned warm temperate rainforest, take a break and enjoy the scenery.

mapList.access_desc: From Orbost take the BuchanOrbost Road for approximately 20km before turning into the Sandy Point Track, proceed down the track until you reach the Mighty Snowy.
mapList.name: Sandy Point
mapList.comments: This is a beautiful section of the Snowy River to roll out a swag on the grassy flat and is ideal for launching a kayak adventure south down the river.

mapList.access_desc: Access from Bairnsdale is along Deptford Rd but is 4WD only (deep river crossing). Access for 2WD is via Bruthen - turn onto Great Alpine Rd, then Engineers Rd and Deptford Rd.
mapList.name: Deptford
mapList.comments: Once a small mining village situated on the Nicholson River, Deptford provides opportunities for both day visitors and campers with good access to the Nicholson River, plenty of spots for a picnic and nearby walks.

mapList.access_desc: Turn off the Buchan Rd onto Long Point Track following the track for 7km. Access is limited to a steep single lane track, four wheel drive access only for the last 200m.
mapList.name: Long Point
mapList.comments: Set on a sandy section of the Mighty Snowy River enjoy your stay getting back to nature.\r\n

mapList.access_desc: Access is via Farm Track off Deptford Rd.
mapList.name: Stantons Place
mapList.comments: A shady picnic area next to the Nicholson River. There is a fire place and picnic table and room for a couple of tents.

mapList.close_reason: This site is currently closed while critical safety works are undertaken.
mapList.access_desc: Access is via the Buchan Road (sign posted). Turn onto Monument Rd following the track up to the tower. This site forms part of the Far East Gippsland Backroad Tour - Stringers Knob Mottle Range.
mapList.name: Stringers Knob Historic Fire Tower
mapList.comments: Enjoy a picnic lunch whilst casting your mind back in time to a bygone era with this experimental single pole fire tower. The tower was built in 1941 following the disastrous 1939 bushfires. The fire spotter's cabin is perched on top of a 28m tall pole made of 2 massive logs (red iron bark & yellow stringy bark trees) spliced lengthwise.

mapList.access_desc: Via 'B' Rd Orbost, following Garnetts Track along until the turnoff to Woods Point Track. A short drive from the township of Orbost, following the river along the fertile Snowy River Flats.
mapList.name: Woods Point
mapList.comments: Set on the sandy banks of the Snowy River in amongst warm temperate rainforest you will find a well maintained selection of camping and day picnicking areas, wildlife watching and river based activities.

mapList.access_desc: Follow the Murrungowar Forest Drive north on the Murrungowar Road, turning right onto Tarlton Track. Travel 2km along  Tarlton Track to Little Cabbage Tree Falls Picnic Area.
mapList.name: Little Cabbage Tree Creek
mapList.comments: Well maintained picnic area with a short walk to a viewing platform at the base of the Little Cabbage Tree Creek Falls

mapList.access_desc: Access to this site is via the Bonang Hwy, turning right on to 4 1/2 mile track and following along to Storers track and following signs down to picnic area.
mapList.name: Youngs Creek
mapList.comments: Set on the fringes of the Youngs Creek warm temperate rainforest this site provides opportunities for picnicking and short walks, with a viewing platform only a short stroll along the creek at Youngs Creek Falls, or take a return walk to the picnic ground through the Youngs Creek loop track, for those a little more energetic take the extended return walk to the old Orbost resevoir.

mapList.access_desc: The site is on Blacks Camp Track, off Deptford Rd. Approx 30 mins drive from Bairnsdale.
mapList.name: Blacks Camp
mapList.comments: This is a picnic area next to a bridge over Clifton Creek. Part of the popular trail bike route, the site can be used for informal camping.

mapList.access_desc: Situated south of Cann River, follow the bitumen down the Tamboon Road and then follow the signs to the right towards Furnell Landing, veer right into Choof Choof Track and proceed to the campground.
mapList.name: Choof Choof
mapList.comments: Situated on the banks of the Cann River this small campsite provides facilities for kayak launching for quick access to the premier fishing grounds of Lake Furnell and Tamboon Inlet

mapList.access_desc: Situated south of Cann River, follow the bitumen down the Tamboon Road and then follow the signs to the right into Furnell Landing.
mapList.name: Furnell Landing
mapList.comments: The gateway to the renowned Tamboon Inlet, launch your boat or enjoy a picnic whilst having a fish off the jetty, or just sit back and listen to the locals tell a yarn about their days fishing adventure!

mapList.access_desc: Access is via the Old Colquhoun Rd off the Princes Hwy, west of Nowa Nowa township.
mapList.name: Costicks Weir
mapList.comments: This is an historic fire dam built in the 1940s by the local Women's Army. It was built to provide a reliable water supply after the disastrous 1939 bushfires. The site is adjacent to the East Gippsland Rail Trail and provides a quiet spot for a picnic or overnight stay.

mapList.access_desc: A short drive from the Princes Highway. Turn off the highway at the sign just 2km from Nowa Nowa and follow the gravel road for 3km to the western end of the bridge and carpark. There is a viewing area at the eastern end of the bridge.
mapList.name: Stony Creek Trestle Bridge
mapList.comments: At 247m long and 20m high, it is the largest standing bridge of its kind in the State, and is listed on the Register of Historic Sites. Built of red ironbark and grey box timber, it is a fine example of the early engineering skills that utilised the resources and materials found on site.

mapList.access_desc: The car park is located on Quarry Rd. Access is via Bruce Rd or Uncles Rd. Quarry is approx. 150m walk from the car park on a gravel surface.
mapList.name: Mississippi Quarry
mapList.comments: An historic granite quarry located in the forest. The site contains a viewing platform and interpretation signs. This is the take off point for the old Mississippi Tramway.

mapList.access_desc: Turn off the Princes Hwy at the sign, follow Uncles Rd for 2km to the turn off. The picnic area is 300m from the intersection.
mapList.name: Log Crossing Picnic Area
mapList.comments: Log Crossing is a spacious shady picnic area with fire places, toilets and picnic tables. This site is a good access point for local walking and mountain bike tracks. This area can be used for overnight camping.

mapList.access_desc: Access is by headin north from Woodspoint for 2 km and you'll turn left into the site.
mapList.name: Jack Scotts
mapList.comments: The perfect place to escape to on a hot summers day, jack Scotts reserve offers largely shaded areas in the foothills of the Upper Goulburn State Forest. With ample space camp and plenty of activities to undertake whilst visiting this is the perfect spot for a weekend get away.

mapList.access_desc: From Jamieson head north towards Jamieson Licola Road and follow Jamieson Licola Road for 29KM before turning left onto Mount Sunday Road for 13KM before reaching the campground.\r\nPlease note: This is an all weather four-wheel drive road.
mapList.name: Wrens Flat

mapList.access_desc: From Woodspoint head South East from the town ship of Woodspoint.
mapList.name: Comet Flat Reserve
mapList.comments: Comet Flat is stretched out along a riverbank about 4 km south-east of Woods Point. A 4WD is recommended to access the camping area from that township  take the Johnson Hill Track. Swimming and fishing are the main activities here, and theres also bushwalking in the area. On chilly nights, toast your toes and some marshmallows by an open fire.

mapList.access_desc: From Mansfield follow the Mt. Buller Rd to Mirimbah. Turn left onto Mt. Stirling Rd and follow to Telephone Box Junction (T.B.J). From here, Follow the Circuit Road 17kms from T.B.J in a clockwise direction, or 29kms in an anti-clockwise direction. The Circuit Rd is normally accessible to all vehicles, but can have rough sections. The Circuit Rd is seasonally closed at T.B.J from the Friday before the Queen's Birthday weekend until the Thursday before the Melbourne Cup Weekend.
mapList.name: Circuit Road

mapList.access_desc: From Mansfield follow the Mt. Buller Rd to Mirimbah. Turn left onto Mt. Stirling Rd and follow to Telephone Box Junction (T.B.J). From here, The Circuit Rd can be driven in either direction and is accessible to all vehicles, but can have rough sections. Circuit Rd is seasonally closed at T.B.J from the Friday before the Queen's Birthday weekend until the Thursday before the Melbourne Cup Weekend. Follow Circuit Rd 18kms from Telephone Box Junction in a clockwise direction, or 28kms in an anti-clockwise direction. Turn onto Clear Hills Tk (4WD only), follow for 2kms. 2WD vehicles can park at the nearby Circuit Rd Picnic Area and walk to the Hut.
mapList.name: Craigs Hut
mapList.comments: Craigs Hut was originally constructed as a film set for the 1983 Australian movie ''The Man from Snowy River.'' The hut was fully rebuilt in 1993 but subsequently destroyed by the 2006 Great Divide wildfire. The hut was again rebuilt in 2008. Located on Clear Hills, the site offers unrivalled and spectacular views over the surrounding high country.

mapList.access_desc: From Licola follow the Licola-Jamieson Rd (C486) for 9km, turn Right onto Link Rd and then Left onto Glencairn Rd. From here continue 18km on Glencairn and Middle Ridge Road. The campsites are located on the right about 1km after Middle Ridge Road crosses the Barkley river.
mapList.name: Rumpffs
mapList.comments: Rumpff's Flat is located on the Mount Skene Creek just prior to it flowing into the Barkley River. This quiet bush setting is accessed via a scenic drive through the unique Barkley State Forest.

mapList.access_desc: Andersons can be found along Donnelly's Creek Rd, south of Code's Flat, just after crossing the bridge.
mapList.name: Andersons
mapList.comments: Located in the Toombon Gold-mines Historic Reserve, this remote and compact bushland site in an open, heathy dry forest is nice stop along the Aberfeldy Back Road Tour.  Set back about 80m from the Alberfeldy river continue through the site itself to find a quite bend in the Aberfeldy river. There is rich mining history in the area with cuts and shafts scattered to the west of the site, care should be taken to remain within the footprint of the site and camping is not recommended here.

mapList.access_desc: From Licola follow the Jamieson-Licola Road (C486) for 21km. The Campsite is on the left just past the Black River Rd.
mapList.name: Connor Plain
mapList.comments: This basic campsite is a convenient stop en route to Jamieson or whilst exploring the Barkly River, Mt Useful and Upper Goulburn Forests.

mapList.access_desc: Junction Camping Ground is located near where the Donnelly Creek meets the Aberfeldy River.  From Erica travel north along the Moe-Rawson Rd continuing into Thompson Valley Rd.  Continue following the bitumen into Thomson Dam Access Rd, turning left into Walhalla Rd at the gravel road intersection. Turn right into Merringtons Tk, and follow towards Merringtons Flat campgrounds, turning left before the flat following a link track to Junction Hut, conintue past the hut and turn right along the River to reach a small camping area.
mapList.name: Junction Camping Ground
mapList.comments: The original huts were built at The Junction in the 1930's by gold fossickers during the depression however the hut that stands today was built in 2015 after the 2013 wildfire. If you are traveling past make sure you stop and check the view from the hut or dip your feet in the cool river.

mapList.access_desc: From Erica travel north along the Moe-Rawson Rd continuing into Thompson Valley Rd.  Continue following the bitumen into Thomson Dam Access Rd, turning left into Walhalla Rd at the gravel road intersection. Turn right into Merringtons Tk, and follow signs to Merringtons Flat campgrounds and the intersection with a link Trk.
mapList.name: Merrington'S Camping Area

mapList.access_desc: From Whalhalla Rd turn right onto Merringtons Trk then turn left onto the link track to Junction Hut. From here cross the creek and continue on Junction track before turning right on Donnellys Creek Rd. Jorgensens hut is on the right just before you cross the creek again.
mapList.name: Jorgenson
mapList.comments: Set beside Donnelly Creek, Jorgenson Flat is one of a number of spacious and open overnight options in the backcountry of Aberfeldy/Nambruc State forests.  A 4WD is a must to make it down the Donnelly Creek Tk from Walhalla Rd to this popular site that features a bush hut, with picnicking facilities for those looking for a nice place to stop. Please note the route in involves a couple of creek crossings.

mapList.access_desc: Located on the river flats adjacent to Donnellys Ck Rd, this site is best accessed via Donnellys Creek Rd from Walhalla Rd. Note that Donnelly's Creek Rd is part of the Aberfeldy 4WD tour.
mapList.name: Little O'Toole'S

mapList.access_desc: This relaxing remote bush camping spot is reached via Donnelly Creek Track, which youll find signposted off Walhalla Rd. A 4WD is needed
mapList.name: O'Toole'S Flat
mapList.comments: A large, clear site perfect to light a fire and enjoy the bush with friends and family, or relax after a day's drive.

mapList.access_desc: Goonans is a stopping point along the Aberfeldy 4WD route along Donnellys Creek in the Aberfeldy/Nambruc State Forest.  You can camp overnight in the recently constructed bush hut or stop for a picnic by the creek.  The closest nearby huts are Jorgensens Flat Hut in the west and Store Point hut to the East.
mapList.name: Goonan'S

mapList.access_desc: From Licola follow the Licola-Jamieson Rd for 9km, turn Right onto Link Rd and then Left onto Glencairn Rd. Barkley Bridge is located approximately 3km up Glencairn Rd where it crosses the Barkley River.
mapList.name: Barkley Bridge
mapList.comments: Barkley Bridge is a small camping area on the Barkley River. The river offers a peaceful picnic setting or a convenient camping area for those exploring Victoria's high country.

mapList.access_desc: The Store Point campground is on Donnelly's Creek Trk, part of the Aberfeldy 4WD tour, this is accessed from Walhalla Rd in the West and Springs Rd in the East, a 4WD is recommended for most of the route.
mapList.name: Store Point
mapList.comments: This scenic and remote creek side site features a tin hut and large grassy clearing for tent camping and is a great base to do some bushwalking to explore some relics of the regions gold mining history.

mapList.access_desc: From Catherine River bridge on Buffalo River Road travel South on East Buffalo Road and East Riley Rd for approximately 28km to reach Rileys Creek hut.
mapList.name: Rileys Hut
mapList.comments: Remote well maintained hut with built in heater located on Rileys Creek.

mapList.access_desc: Approximately 30 minutes or 35km north of Heyfield on the Licola Rd C486.
mapList.name: Cheynes Bridge
mapList.comments:
Cheyne's Bridge campsite area has easy access for caravans and camper trailers. Several separated overnight camping areas are available on the East side of the bridge and a day area is located on the West side.
This site is a popular destination for group 4WD trips with medium and hard four wheel drive tracks situated nearby. The Macalister river winds past the site and provides swimming and paddle sport activities when the water is higher. 
A further 30 minutes north of Cheynes Bridge is the small township of Licola which is a Gateway to the Victorian High Country and its various recreation opportunities. 
We ask that visitors please take their rubbish home so that the site can be enjoyed by the next visitors.

mapList.access_desc: From the township of Heyfield take Weir Rd North for 10km and turn Right onto Lanigan Rd. Turn Left off Lanigan Rd onto Millers Rd and follow for 7.5km. At Bulldog Junction turn right and continue on Huggetts Rd until you reach the Mt Hedrick Picnic Area on the left.
mapList.name: Mount Hedrick Picnic Area

mapList.access_desc: From the township of Heyfield take Weir Rd North for 10km and turn Right onto Lanigan Rd. Turn Left off Lanigan Rd onto Millers Rd and follow for 7.5km. At Bulldog Junction turn right onto Huggett's Rd and then right on Corner Creek Track. After 1km turn right onto the Pearson's Point Lookout access track.
mapList.name: Pearson Point
mapList.comments: Pearson's Point provides scenic views of the Heyfield/Lake Glenmaggie area and further to the Strzelecki Ranges. To the west the forested foothills of the lower Macalister River catchment can be viewed stretching to Mt Useful and Licola.

mapList.access_desc: Huggetts is located around 15km or 25 minutes North of the township of Newry and can be accessed via Three Chain Rd and then Kentucky Rd. At the end of Kentucky Rd turn left onto Huggetts Track and travel for 4km on this 4wd route to the Camping area.
mapList.name: Huggetts Crossing
mapList.comments: A popular family campsite that also caters for picnickers, Huggetts is a great hub from which to explore the Avon-Mt Hedrick Natural Features and Scenic Reserve. This can be done either by foot on the Avon River and Mt Hedrick Walking Tracks or by 4WD on the Avon Crossing 4WD route. The Avon River Walking track begins at Huggetts Crossing. The Mt Hedrick Walking Track takes off from Huggetts track around 1km to the South of the campsite.

mapList.access_desc: Huggetts Lookout is located around 20 minutes North of the township of Newry and can be accessed via Three Chain Rd and then Kentucky Rd. Turn left onto Huggetts Track and after 1.5km the lookout is on the left.
mapList.name: Huggetts Lookout
mapList.comments: Huggett's Lookout (381m) is a convenient stop on the way to Huggett's Crossing campsite. It offers pleasant views of the hills and to the West and provides a convenient drop off or picnic stop whilst completing the Mt Hedrick Walking Track. Mt Hedrick (448m) is located to the Southwest at the end of the ridgeline and Ben Crauchan (824m) can be viewed to the Northwest.

mapList.access_desc: Green Hill Lookout is located on Huggetts Track via Kentucky Rd approximately 15 minutes from the township of Newry.
mapList.name: Green Hill Lookout
mapList.comments: The rocky outcrop provides pleasant views into the rugged Avon River valley and hills to the North.

mapList.access_desc: From Maffra take the Maffra-Briagolong Road out of Maffra towards Boisdale. Continue through Boisdale towards Valencia Creek. Turn Left onto Luckman's Road (3km beyond Boisdale) and finally right into Warrigal-Toms Creek Road. From here turn left onto Green Hills Road and then right onto Channel Track. Please note, the nearby Channel Road does not access the Channels carpark.
mapList.name: The Channels
mapList.comments: This picnic area is located on the hill above 'The Channels' on the Avon river with shady casuarinas in abundance. From the lookout it is a short but steep walk down to the magnificent gorge created by the Avon river carving its way through silt and sandstone over millennia.  Crags punctuate the riverbed, creating a system of pools and rapids which provide habitat for a variety of aquatic life.

mapList.access_desc: Nicholson Rocks Picnic Area is located off Kentucky Rd approximately 15 minutes drive from the townships of Heyfield and Briagolong.
mapList.name: Nicholson Rocks Picnic Area

mapList.access_desc: From Maffra take the Maffra-Briagolong Road out of Maffra towards Boisdale. Continue through Boisdale towards Valencia Creek. Turn Left onto Luckman's Road (3km beyond Boisdale) and finally right into Warrigal - Tom's Road. Continue straight on Dermody Road to the campsite.
mapList.name: Dermody'S
mapList.comments: Dermody's is an easily accessible campsite in the Avon-Mt Hedrick NFSR which is suitable for families. Nestled alongside the Avon River, the water is just a short walk from this camping area.

mapList.access_desc: From the township of Boisdale travel North on Boisdale-Valencia Creek Road to Wombat Rd. Turn left off Wombat Rd onto OKeefe Rd. Continue straight after the first two campsites to reach Wombat campsite C.
mapList.name: Wombat Crossing Camp Site C
mapList.comments: Small campsite at the end of O'Keefes Rd. Campsite is located in the forest with walking access only to the river.

mapList.access_desc: From the township of Boisdale travel North on Boisdale-Valencia Creek Road to Wombat Rd. Turn left off Wombat Rd onto OKeefe Rd The access track is off to the left after approximately 2km. Follow this track for a couple of hundred metres to Wombat campsite B.
mapList.name: Wombat Crossing Camp Site B
mapList.comments: The middle and largest Wombat campsite. Walking access only to the river.

mapList.access_desc: From the township of Boisdale travel North on Boisdale-Valencia Creek Road to Wombat Rd. Turn left off Wombat Rd onto OKeefe Rd and follow for approximately 1.3km to the Wombat campsite A on the left.
mapList.name: Wombat Crossing Camp Site A

mapList.access_desc: From Boisdale take the Boisdale-Valencia Creek Road To Valencia Creek. Turn right onto Valencia Creek Briagolong Road and then left onto Moroka Rd. Follow for 30 minutes or 17km until you reach the crossing.
mapList.name: Paddy Lees Crossing
mapList.comments: This picnic area is located on Valencia Creek.

mapList.access_desc: From Dargo Rd (C601) head Northwest along the rough 2wd route of Wonnangatta Rd for approximately 15km or 30 minutes.
mapList.name: Black Snake Creek
mapList.comments: This campground is situated near the junction of Black Snake Creek and the Wonnangatta River and provides a good jumping off point for 4WD trips further along the Wonnangatta Rd or around Dargo. Fishing is a popular activity in the Wonnangatta River and the Black Snake Creek Historic Walk can be accessed from Black Snake Creek 4WD Track. There are a number of campsites available with picnic tables, firepits and a toilet facility. \r\n

mapList.access_desc: Black Snake Creek East is situated approximately 500m Northeast of Black Snake Creek campground along Black Snake Creek 4WD Track. It can be accessed from the Wonnangatta Road approximately 15km or 30 minutes from its intersection with the Dargo Road (C601).
mapList.name: Black Snake East
mapList.comments: This is a smaller campsite to the Northeast of Black Snake Creek main camping area. It provides closer access to the Black Snake Historic Walking Track.

mapList.access_desc: From Boisdale take the Boisdale-Valencia Creek Road To Valencia Creek. Turn right onto Valencia Creek Briagolong Road and then left onto Moroka Rd. Follow for approximately 9km or 15 minutes, the campsite access track is located on the left.
mapList.name: Valencia Creek Picnic Area

mapList.access_desc: Appears in Access page
mapList.name: Collins Hut

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong travel around 30km or 45minutes on the rough 2wd route of Freestone Creek Rd and then around 3km or 10 minutes along the 4wd route of Lee Creek Track.
mapList.name: Lee Creek Picnic Area

mapList.access_desc: Located just off the Dargo Road, 20km South of Dargo.
mapList.name: Castleburn Creek
mapList.comments: Set on the Castleburn Creek, this campsite has a number of camping areas available and is sheltered by the ridge to the North.

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong follow the Freestone Creek Road approximately 20km or 30 minutes. Turn left down the access track and Shadey's Place campsite is located around 200m from the road on the Freestone Creek.
mapList.name: Shadeys Place
mapList.comments: Shadey's Place is located a bit further off Freestone Creek Road and offers a quiet bush setting for a picnic or camp by the creek.

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong follow the Freestone Creek Road approximately 12km or 15 minutes, turn left onto McKinnon's Point Track (4WD only) and follow to the campsite located above Freestone Creek.
mapList.name: Mckinnon'S Point
mapList.comments: Another campsite available on the Freestone Creek. Mckinnon's Point is the halfway point of the Freestone Walking Track and provides a convenient spot to stop for a picnic. The track from Freestone Creek Road also provides stunning views of the creek and surrounding cliffs.

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong follow the Freestone Creek Road approximately 15km or 20 minutes to Carney's Camp on the Freestone Creek.
mapList.name: Carney'S Camp
mapList.comments: Carney's is is a small site located on a bend in the creek with plenty of space for swimming.

mapList.access_desc: 15km South of Dargo or around 3km downstream from the Waterford Bridge.
mapList.name: Meyers Flat
mapList.comments: Located at a convenient spot between the Wonnangatta River and the Dargo Road, a couple of camping areas are available here along with a toilet facility.

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong follow the Freestone Creek Road approximately 24km or 40 minutes to Johnston's Flat. Turn left down the access track and the campsite is located on the Freestone Creek.
mapList.name: Johnston'S Flat
mapList.comments: A small campsite providing an alternative to the nearby Lloyd's Knob. This campsite is off the road and has close access to the Freestone Creek.

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong follow the Freestone Creek Road approximately 24km or 40 minutes to the Lloyd's Knob Track. Turn left and the campsites can be found on the right, prior to crossing Freestone Creek. Alternatively it is located 16km or 35 minutes along Freestone Creek Rd from Bairnsdale-Dargo Rd (C601).
mapList.name: Lloyd'S Knob
mapList.comments: A slightly larger campsite, Lloyd's Knob provides the last camping option along Freestone Creek.

mapList.access_desc: From the intersection with Beverleys Rd travel 24.5km or 25 minutes North on the Dargo Road (C601) to the Pretty Boy Hill carpark.
mapList.name: Pretty Boy Hill
mapList.comments: Just past Cobbannah the Pretty Boy Hill picnic area provides a rest place en route to Dargo or a jumping off point for the Granite Creek and Track 96 walking tracks.

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong travel around 30km or 45 minutes on the rough 2wd route of Freestone Creek Rd. From this campsite it is a further 12.5km North to the Bairnsdale-Dargo Rd (C601).
mapList.name: Lee Creek Camping Area
mapList.comments: Lee Creek Camping Area is located at the junction of the Freestone Creek Road and Lee Creek Track. The site is located on Sportsmans Creek and is the last campsite on Freestone Creek Road before it continues to wind its way up to Cobbannah.

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong follow the Freestone Creek Road approximately 10.5km or 500m past the Lower Blue Pool carpark.
mapList.name: Froam
mapList.comments: A small campsite on the banks of the Freestone Creek. This is a close but slightly quieter setting than the Blue Pool Camping Area. Froam is located on the Freestone Walking Track.

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong follow the Freestone Creek Road approximately 10km or 10 minutes to the Blue Pool carpark area. The lower carpark located just past the main Blue Pool area.
mapList.name: Blue Pool Lower

mapList.access_desc: From Briagolong follow the Freestone Creek Road approximately 10km or 10 minutes to the Blue Pool carpark area.
mapList.name: Blue Pool Upper

mapList.access_desc: The Briagolong Red Gum Reserve is located just North of the township of Briagolong on the East side of the Briagolong Road. A picnic area with information shelter is located on the North side of OConnor Road which cuts through the centre of the reserve. All walks can be accessed from here.
mapList.name: Red Gum Reserve
mapList.comments: The Briagolong Red Gum Reserve displays plains grassy woodland in the traditional home of the Braiakaulung people. From the 1870s the area was part of a timber reserve which supplied a resource for products such as road pavers or railway sleepers. The 278 acres of today's reserve provides a rare and important example of a once prominent Gippsland ecosystem type. This reserve will change its appearance over time as the Eucalyptus tereticornis woodland fully matures.

mapList.access_desc: Located 15 minutes from Bairnsdale. Travel north through Wy Yung and follow the Bullumwaal Rd. The intersection to Mount Taylor is where the bitumen road turns to gravel.
mapList.name: Mount Taylor
mapList.comments: Open camping and picnic area set amongst tall eucalypt trees. This location is central to the Mt Taylor mountain bike trails.

mapList.access_desc: Head East from Corryong along the Murray Valley Highway (B400) for approximately 6kms. Turn Right staying on the B400  for approximately 2.4kms. Turn onto Fishers Track then travel for approximately 3.5kms to reach Mount Elliot summit. Please note Fishers Track passes through private property, ensure all gates are closed at all times. Access is all weather 4WD but extreme wet weather may force the property owner to lock the gate. \r\n
mapList.name: Mount Elliot
mapList.comments: Mount Elliot offers spectacular views of the Corryong township and surrounding valleys.  This is a popular hang-gliding launch site and also offers picnic sites and limited tent/swag camping sites. A great place to observe from a high vantage point and explore the mountain ranges of the wonderful Upper Murray including remnants of the \flying swagmans\" hut. No amenities are present at this site.

mapList.access_desc: At Shelley, turn south off the Murray Valley Highway onto Avondale Road.  Travel approximately 12 km south and turn left onto Beetoomba Road. Travel approximately 1km along Beetoomba Road and turn left onto the Avondale Gardens access track.  Note: Avondale and Beetoomba Roads are used for timber haulage by large vehicles and carrying a UHF for communication is advised. Follow any road advisory signs, road may be slippery when wet.
mapList.name: Avondale Gardens
mapList.comments: Avondale Gardens is what remains of a homestead site that was established after World War 2 by Derek and Peg Bird (circa 1950). The majestic gardens are comprised of towering exotic trees, unique shrubs, and handcrafted stonewalls, which are a reminder of a once thriving cattle/sheep grazing station that operated on the Koetong Plateau. A spectacular visual display can be witnessed in Autumn as the leaves turn from green to red, yellow, orange, and brown or a cool retreat during the warmer months.

mapList.access_desc: From the main street of Yackandandah follow Bells Flat Rd for approx. 3km until you meet Service Basin Rd. Continue along Service Basin Rd, which then becomes Yack Gate Rd, for approx. 1km to the site located to your left at the crest of the hill.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Creek

mapList.access_desc: Grays Campsite is located approx 20kms from the township of Corryong. Travel down Thowgla Road from Corryong for 16km before turning left just past the bridge at Nariel Gap Rd intersection. Travel approximately 4kms further until you reach Grays Campsite. \r\n
mapList.name: Grays Campsite
mapList.comments: Situated on the banks of the pristine Thowgla Creek, this peaceful location offers limited camp sites suited to small camper trailers, tents and swags as well as picnic and BBQ facilities. During past mining activities, this was the site for the lower township store, with gold mine diggings still visible today. Use the site as a base to explore the high country or just stop for a day visit. Some sites may be subject to flooding during the winter months.

mapList.access_desc: From the main street of Yackandandah follow Bells Flat Rd for approx. 3km until you meet Service Basin Rd. Continue along Service Basin Rd, which then becomes Yack Gate Rd, for approx. 1.2km to the site access track that drops steeply to your left. Not recommended for 2WD vehicles in the wet.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Creek 1

mapList.access_desc: From the main street of Yackandandah follow Bells Flat Rd for approx. 3km until you meet Service Basin Rd. Continue along Service Basin Rd, which then becomes Yack Gate Rd, for approx. 1.5km to the site access track to your left. Follow the rough 4x4 track for approx. 300m to the site.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Creek 2

mapList.access_desc: From the main street of Yackandandah follow Bells Flat Rd for approx. 3km until you meet Service Basin Rd. Continue along Service Basin Rd, which then becomes Yack Gate Rd, for approx. 1.7km to the two site access tracks to your right.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Creek 3

mapList.access_desc: From the main street of Yackandandah follow Bells Flat Rd for approx. 3km until you meet Service Basin Rd. Continue along Service Basin Rd, which then becomes Yack Gate Rd, for approx. 1.7km to the intersection of Yack Gate Rd and Gravel Pit Tk. The road is well gravelled and access is 2WD and suitable for trailers.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Trail Bike Visitor Area
mapList.comments: Yackandandah Trail Bike Visitor area is a great place to start exploring the numerous tracks within Yackandandah Creek and Stanley State Forest. The site has ample space for several vehicles and trailers and adjacent to the car park is toilet facilities and information about the surrounding area.

mapList.access_desc: From the Myrtleford-Yackandandah Rd on the edge of Yackandandah, head south on Back Creek Rd for 1.1km to Kirby Flat Rd. Follow Kirby Flat Rd for 1.1km to Moyle Rd. Take Moyle Rd for 600m to No.1 Rd. Head west on No.1 Rd for approx. 1km to the access track that drops steeply to your right. 4x4 vehicle access only.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Creek 8

mapList.access_desc: From the main street of Yackandandah follow Bells Flat Rd for approx. 3km until you meet Service Basin Rd. Continue along Service Basin Rd, which then becomes Yack Gate Rd, for approx. 1.9km to the site to your right.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Creek 4

mapList.access_desc: From the Myrtleford-Yackandandah Rd on the edge of Yackandandah, head south on Back Creek Rd for 1.1km to Kirby Flat Rd. Follow Kirby Flat Rd for 1.1km to Moyle Rd. Take Moyle Rd for 600m to No.1 Rd. Head west on No.1 Rd for approx. 550m to Kohns Spur Tk to your right which accesses the site. 4x4 vehicle access only.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Creek 9

mapList.access_desc: From the main street of Yackandandah follow Bells Flat Rd for approx. 3km until you meet Service Basin Rd. Continue along Service Basin Rd, which then becomes Yack Gate Rd, for approx. 2.4km to No. 1 Link Rd. Head south on No.1 Link Rd for approx. 350m to Willow Tree Rd. Head West on Willow Tree Rd over the bridge to the site.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Creek 6

mapList.access_desc: Bullocky Creek Campsite is located approximately 24kms from Corryong. Travel south along Thowgla Road from Corryong for 16km before turning left just over the bridge at the Nariel Gap intersection. Travel a further 4kms to where the road becomes Walkers Road at Greys campsite. From here Bullocky campsite is a further 4kms along Walkers Road. 2WD dry weather and 4WD all weather access.\r\n
mapList.name: Bullocky Creek Campsite
mapList.comments: Located on the banks of the Thougla Creek, the soothing sounds of running water, and wildlife ensure a relaxing visit.  Offering both day visitor and overnight camping options with toilet, picnic, and BBQ facilities, this is the perfect place to pull in for a rest.

mapList.access_desc: From the main street of Yackandandah follow Bells Flat Rd for approx. 3km until you meet Service Basin Rd. Continue along Service Basin Rd, which then becomes Yack Gate Rd, for approx. 2.4km to No. 1 Link Rd. Head south on No.1 Link Rd for approx. 1km to the site entrance to your right. Not recommended for 2WD vehicles in the wet.
mapList.name: Yackandandah Creek 7

mapList.access_desc: From Beechworth head approx. 7 km south along the Buckland Gap Rd (towards Myrtleford/Gapsted) until you reach the Buckland Gap. Head East onto Lady Newton Drive for 250m then onto Jensens Tk. Bates Dam is well sign posted once on Lady Newton Drive.
mapList.name: Bates Dam

mapList.access_desc: From Beechworth head approx. 7 km south along the Buckland Gap Rd (towards Myrtleford/Gapsted) until you reach the Buckland Gap. Head East on Lady Newton Drive for approx. 3km to the intersection of Six Mile Rd. Alternatively Six Mile Rd can be followed south from Stanley for approx. 3km to the intersection of Lady Newton Drive.
mapList.name: Clark Corner

mapList.access_desc: From Beechworth head approx. 7 km south along the Buckland Gap Rd (towards Myrtleford/Gapsted) until you reach the Buckland Gap. Head East on Lady Newton Drive for approx. 2km to the site.
mapList.name: Murmungee Lookout
mapList.comments: An amazing view over the cropping and grazing lands of the Murmungee basin. Further South is the Ovens Valley, and on the horizon the Victorian Alps from Mt Buffalo to Mt Buller.

mapList.access_desc: Dart River campsite is located approx 2.6kms along Gibb Range Road from the intersection with Benambra-Corryong Road.  Traveling along Benambra-Corryong Road (C545b), approximately 75 kms from Benambra and 46kms from Corryong turn west and stay to the left as there is a couple of tracks heading off from this intersection. 2WD dry weather & 4WD all weather access.\r\n
mapList.name: Dart River Campsite
mapList.comments: Nestled in a small secluded valley, this is the perfect retreat from the heat of summer. The site abuts the headwaters of the Dart River and consists of open grassy areas great for day visitors or overnight stays. There is a strong history of mining in the area and this site would be a good base location for exploring the broader area.   \r\n

mapList.access_desc: Travel approximately 23kms along Dunstans Road from Benambra-Corryong Raod. Turn into Ski Hut Track and travel for approx 1.5kms. Assess is 2WD dry weather only and 4WD all weather. \r\n
mapList.name: Ski Hut
mapList.comments: Situated amongst majestic Alpine Ash trees is this historic high country hut. Ski Hut (Lind Lodge) has a rich history and has been used for generations by cross country skiers as a base or for refuge during poor weather.  Listen out at night for the slow, mournful woo-hoo of the Powerful Owl. Pitch a tent or roll out a swag, there is enough room for small groups of campers.  \r\n

mapList.access_desc: Pinnibar-Gibsons Hut is located 35kms along Dunstans Road from its intersection with the Benambra-Corryong Road. Access is 4WD all weather conditions. NOTE: seasonal road closures exist adjacent to the site, which may limit 4WDing opportunities during the closure period. \r\n
mapList.name: Pinnibar Gibsons Hut
mapList.comments: Take a glimpse into the past with what would have been a common scene across the high country in the mid 1900`s. Explore Gibson`s hut and the cattle yards, which are still used today. A great location for large and small groups with open grassed areas, access to a high country hut and a reliable mountain stream. Suited to small off-road caravans/camper trailers, tents and swags. BBQ and picnic table facilities available onsite with no toilet present.\r\n\r\n

mapList.access_desc: Located 2kms north of Mitta Mitta township on the Omeo Highway.\r\n
mapList.name: The Mill
mapList.comments: Located on the site of an old saw mill, this is an open grassed area with easy access to the mighty Mitta Mitta River and is popular with anglers. In September, the surrounding area is covered with gold flowers of the endemic Poverty Wattle. A great base for those wanting to explore Mitta Mitta and surrounds whilst having seclusion and tranquility.

mapList.access_desc: Located centrally in the Mitta Mitta township alongside the Omeo Highway.
mapList.name: Mitta Mitta Historic Reserve
mapList.comments: A perfect starting point to discover the valley's historic and natural wonders. This site contains a collection of old mining equipment from the local area, including dredge buckets, water wheel and old mining hut relocated to the site. It is also the starting point for several scenic and historic walking trails.

mapList.access_desc: Travel South from Corrong along the Benambra-Corryong road for approximately 52km, then, turn left onto Wheelers Creek Rd from Benambra-Corryong Road. Travel approx 7.5kms to reach campsite. 2WD dry weather only & 4WD all weather access.\r\n
mapList.name: Ohagens Campsite
mapList.comments: Ohagens Campsite is a small secluded campsite located on the banks of pristine Wheelers Creek. Enjoy an overnight stay in the tranquility of the remote forest environment, explore the surrounding areas rich in history, or have a fish for trout (appropriate season) in Wheelers Creek.  This site is suited to small off-road camper trailers, tents and swags. There have been recent additions of a BBQ  and picnic table, however, there are no toilet facilities.  \r\n

mapList.access_desc: Travel South from Corryong along the Benambra-Corryong road for approximately 52km, then, turn left onto Wheelers Creek Rd from Benambra-Corryong Road. Travel approx 16kms to reach Wheelers Creek Hut.  Access is 2WD dry weather only & 4WD all weather.\r\n
mapList.name: Wheelers Creek Hut
mapList.comments: Wheelers Creek Hut is one of the Upper Murray districts more iconic high country huts.  Built in 1976 by the Forests Commission, this hut exudes a relaxing charm that lures visitors from all around Australia.  Situated in remote state forest and adjacent to the pristine Wheelers Creek, be engrossed in the wilderness environment surrounded by endless exploring opportunities.

mapList.access_desc: Paddy Joys Camp is accessed via Wheelers Creek Road just past Wheelers Creek Hut Recreation site. Suited to 4WD all weather conditions.
mapList.name: Paddy Joy Camp
mapList.comments: This is a small isolated site boasting tranquility and direct access to a remote mountain stream.  The site is one of the most basic camp sites, offering no improvements and suited only to swags and tents. Access to this site is by 4WD only.

mapList.access_desc: The site is accessed via the Reform Hill walking track network. The best starting point is Jones Reserve located on the Great Alpine Road in Myrtleford between the Hardware store and Rays Ski Shop.
mapList.name: Reform Hill Hume And Hovell Monument Site

mapList.access_desc: The site can be accessed via the Reform Hill walking track network. The best starting point is Jones Reserve located on the Great Alpine Road in Myrtleford between the Hardware store and Rays Ski Shop. It is also possible to drive to the site via Halls rd (off Standish st) in Myrtleford, but is not recommended for buses,  large vehicles or trailers.
mapList.name: Reform Hill Lookout
mapList.comments: The lookout provides views of the Ovens Valley, Mt.Buffalo and the Victorian Alps.

mapList.access_desc: Right in the heart of Myrtleford beside the Great Alpine Road, the site is located between the Hardware store and Ray's Ski shop. Parking is available along the edge of the road.
mapList.name: Reform Hill Gold Battery
mapList.comments: Located at Jones Reserve beside the Murray to Mountains rail trail in the heart of Myrtleford, this site offers a welcome rest stop in town and access to the Reform Hill State Forest.

mapList.access_desc: Approximately 12kms South of Mitta Mitta and 96kms North of Omeo on the Omeo Highway (C543), turn onto Holloways Log Road and travel for 700 mtrs to the campsite. 2WD & 4WD all weather access.\r\n
mapList.name: Snowy Creek Picnic And Camping Area Mitta Mitta
mapList.comments: Located on the banks of the pure Snowy Creek, there are two great campsites separated by the creek itself. This is a great place for swimming, fishing and as a base for 4WDing on the surrounding tracks in the area (subject to seasonal closures). The site lends itself to day visits or overnight stays with BBQ facilities at both sites and a pit toilet. This is a relatively small site so space may be limited, and it may also be subjected to flooding during winter months.

mapList.access_desc: Located 27km south of Oxley on the Wangaratta-Whitfield road, a couple of kilometres past Edi itself. Access is either via Wangaratta from the north or by taking the Snow Road turnoff from the Hume Hwy at Glenrowan from the south.
mapList.name: Edi Cutting

mapList.access_desc: Located approx 85 kms from Omeo township and approx 22 kms from Mitta Mitta township on the sealed Omeo Highway  C543. Access to this site is 2WD all weather conditions.\r\n
mapList.name: Lightning Creek
mapList.comments: Lightning Creek is a unique campsite, offering large open camping and picnic areas alongside the picturesque Lightning and Snowy Creeks in a highly remote forest environment.  Once a loggers campsite, this now tranquil site is scattered with logging artefacts, giving indicators of a once industrious hub.  Lightning Creek is a destination in its own rite, or can serve as a base to explore both North East Victoria and/or Gippsland.

mapList.access_desc: From the Kiewa valley Highway at Tawonga, follow Mountain Creek Rd (sealed) and Trapper Gap Rd (unsealed 2WD), and at Trappers Gap turn left onto Eskdale Spur Track (4WD only).  Follow Eskdale Spur Track north/west for approx. 12 km to the summit of Mt Emu.
mapList.name: Mt Emu
mapList.comments: A clearing that incorporates a hang gliding launch pad, with views across the Kiewa Valley and the mountains to the south and west.

mapList.access_desc: Access is approximately 27kms from the township of Tawonga (Kiewa Valley) via Ryders Lane, Mountain Creek Road, Camp Creek Road and The Hollow Way Road. Traveling a further 19kms along The Hollow Way Road will connect with the Omeo Highway.  4WD all weather conditions. Road subject to deep snow during the winter months.
mapList.name: The Hollow Mitta Mitta
mapList.comments: The Hollow Mitta Mitta is a secluded site suitable for a day visitor or overnight stay.  Set high in elevation and amongst Alpine Ash forest, this was once the site of a loggers hut, which was burnt down during bushfires.  This is more suited to small camper trailers, tents, and swags.

mapList.access_desc: Drive or walk from Tawonga Gap south along Tawonga Gap Track for approx. 1 km.  Suitable for high clearance or 4WD vehicles only.
mapList.name: Tawonga Gap Track Lookout
mapList.comments: A small lookout under the power transmission lines that lead from the Kiewa hydro-electric power scheme, with views over the township of Mount Beauty to Mount Bogong.

mapList.access_desc: Located within the township of Bright, the main entrance is in Mountbatten Ave, with other entrances via Hawthorn Lane or Cherry Walk.
mapList.name: Memorial Arboretum
mapList.comments: A park-like setting with views to the surrounding forests; incorporating various tree species, and memorials to local State government department forestry staff who died while engaged in forest fire related activities.

mapList.access_desc: From the centre of Bright drive walk or ride approx. 1.5 km south up Bakers Gully Rd to the sign shelter on the left that is at the start of the walking track.
mapList.name: Bakers Gully Reservoirs
mapList.comments: A quiet oasis with two short walking track loops around the dams provide good opportunities for bird watching on the outskirts of Bright.

mapList.access_desc: From Porepunkah, head south at the large round-about onto the sealed Buckland Valley Road for approximately 13 km.
mapList.name: Buckland Valley Bridge
mapList.comments: A grassy clearing by the Buckland River next to the historic Buckland Bridge, surrounded by native forest.

mapList.access_desc: From Myrtleford, travel 31km sth along the Buffalo River Rd, to the Rose River Rd intersection. From here it becomes the Abbeyards Rd which is a gravelled road, suitable for 2WDs, caravans and camper trailers. Travel a further 3km to the campground.
mapList.name: Blades
mapList.comments: Blades is the first campground along the Buffalo River and only 12km from Marshalls Ridge Recreation Area at Lake Buffalo.  It is a small basic bush campground with  2 campsites, campfire pits and picnic tables.

mapList.access_desc: Turn off the Great Alpine Rd approx. 8km north of Harrietville/16km south of Bright and drive along the gravel road for approx. 500m to the camping area.
mapList.name: Smoko
mapList.comments: Informal camping set amongst Swamp Gums next to the Ovens River.

mapList.access_desc: From Myrtleford, travel 31km sth along the Buffalo River Rd, to the Rose River Rd intersection. From here it becomes the Abbeyards Rd which is a gravelled road, suitable for 2WDs, caravans and camper trailers. Travel a further 5.5km to the campground.
mapList.name: Tea Tree

mapList.access_desc: From Porepunkah, head south at the large roundabout onto the Buckland Valley Road for approximately 19 km, where the camping area is located on the left. The Buckland Valley Road is sealed for the first 13km to Buckland Bridge and then unsealed for the remainder. The unsealed section is suitable for two wheel drive access throughout the year, however access to the site may be slippery in wet weather.
mapList.name: Ah Youngs
mapList.comments: A grassy clearing near the Buckland River, surrounded by native forest.

mapList.access_desc: From Myrtleford, travel 31km sth along the Buffalo River Rd, to the Rose River Rd intersection. From here it becomes the Abbeyards Rd which is a gravelled road, suitable for high clearance 2WDs,small caravans and camper trailers. Travel a further 6.5km to the campground.
mapList.name: Manna Gum
mapList.comments: Large shady popular camping site on the Buffalo river with toilet, site can be busy during holiday periods and is a lovely spot to visit during the quieter times of the year.

mapList.access_desc: From Porepunkah take the Great Alpine Road turning left onto Buckland Valley Road and follow for 20Km before coming to camp flat on your left.
mapList.name: Camp Flat
mapList.comments: Positioned in the Buckland Valley and with the Buckland River streaming through the centre of the campground you couldn't find anywhere more scenic. The campground is large and offers room for small to large sized groups with large grassy areas and lots of places to explore.

mapList.access_desc: From Myrtleford, travel 31km south along the Buffalo River Rd, to the Rose River Rd intersection.  From here the road becomes Abbeyards Rd which is gravel suitable for 2WDs and camper trailers.  Travel a further 18.5km to the campground.
mapList.name: Abbeyards
mapList.comments: Abbeyards is small site along the Buffalo river with campfire pits and picnic tables available for use. \r\nThere is a nice swimming hole and shade by the river.

mapList.name: Forest Road Horse Visitor Area
mapList.comments: horse unloading area

mapList.access_desc: From Powelltown, head East along the Yarra Junction - Noojee Road, and turn right onto Turners Road. Follow Turners road until you reach Learmonth Creek Road. Turn Left onto Learmonth Creek road and continue until you reach Bunyip Road. The Seven Acre Rock picnic area is located 500 metres east of the junction of Learmonth Creek Road and Bunyip Road.\r\n
mapList.name: Seven Acre Rock Picnic Area

mapList.access_desc: Take the Warburton Highway from Lilydale, when you reach the traffic lights in Yarra Junction turn right and travel on the Yarra-Junction-Noojee Road towards Powelltown for 15km. The Powelltown Picnic Area is just into town directly opposite the DELWP office.
mapList.name: Powelltown Picnic Area
mapList.comments: Near the Little Yarra River and just off Powelltown's main street, this site offers facilities for day visitors and access to walks (Walk Into History and Reids Tramline). An old timber bogie used to haul timber from the forests sits in-situ.

mapList.name: Latrobe Horse Visitor Area
mapList.comments: horse unloading area

mapList.access_desc: From Powelltown, head east along the Yarra Junction - Noojee Road (C425) for 6km then turn left up Big Creek Road. Travel along Big Creek Road for 11.5km and pull into the Starlings Gap car park on your right. \r\nFrom Warburton Travel along the Warburton - Woodspoint Road (C511) for 10km and Turn Right onto Brahams Road. Continue for 13km and turn right onto Big Creek Road. After approximately 8km, you will reach Starlings Gap on your left.
mapList.name: Starlings Gap
mapList.comments: The forests surrounding Starlings Gap consist of a mixture of Cool Temperate Rainforest, Wet and Damp forest vegetation classes. It is rich in Mountain Ash (Eucalyptus regnans), towering above the moist ferny understorey that once provided harsh and remote employment conditions to locals in the Warburton and Powelltown areas. These forests supplied surrounding districts and Melbourne with timber for buildings, housing and furniture, and contributed to urban growth in the suburbs from the early 1900s.

mapList.access_desc: Limberlost trail bike visitor area is located approximately 90 kilometers east of Melbourne between the towns of Powelltown and Noojee along the Yarra Junction - Noojee road. Roads are sealed the entire way from Melbourne as well as  from East Gippsland. \r\n
mapList.name: Limberlost
mapList.comments: Located deep in the forest but with good sealed road access, Limberlost provides an unloading area for trail bikes wishing to explore the broader forest as well as a convenient picnic spot just off the Yarra Junction - Noojee Road.\r\n

mapList.access_desc: Big Pats Creek Recreation Area sits 6km south-east from Warburton. To get there, continue east through Warburton for 4km and turn right into Riverside Drive after crossing the Yarra River. After 600m turn left into Big Pats Creek rd continue on through the small settlement of Big Pats Creek. After crossing a bridge, turn right into Smythes Creek rd. After 1km, the recreation area and car park is reached.
mapList.name: Big Pats Recreation Area
mapList.comments: Big Pats Recreation area is situated along the banks of Big Pats Creek under towering Manna Gum trees. This site is a popular stop for picnicking, camping and often used as the beginning of the 2-night Walk Into History hike.\r\nThis site also the starting point for the Richards Curves and Richards Tramline walking tracks.

mapList.access_desc: Latrobe River Picnic and Camping Area is located approximately 90 kilometres east of Melbourne.  Turn left just 500m up Ada River Road which is located between the towns of Powelltown and Noojee along the Yarra Junction - Noojee road. With the exception of Ada River Road and the campsite its self, access is entirely on sealed roads from Melbourne as well as from the east, if heading from East Gippsland. \r\n
mapList.name: La Trobe River Picnic And Camping Area
mapList.comments: Latrobe River Picnic and Camping Area is just a short walk away from the Latrobe River itself and is situated within easy access of a main road. The large area is within the heart of the Latrobe State Forest and is within a short distance of many worthwhile destinations such as the Ada Tree and Seven Acre Rock.\r\n

mapList.access_desc:
The Ada No. 2 site can only be accessed via foot along the Walk into History. If commencing your journey from Starlings Gap, the Ada Tree or New Ada Mill, head south at the crossroads and walk for a further 200m. upon approaching the site you will cross a swamp foot crossing that weaves through tea tree and back onto the old tramline.
Alternatively, Ada No. 2 can be reached from Dowey Spur Rd by heading north along the Walk into History for 1km.
mapList.name: New Ada No2 Mill
mapList.comments: One of two key camp sites along the Walk into History. The Ada No. 2 Mill was destroyed in the 1939 bushfires, however the relics of structures and machinery around the campsite provide the visitor with a sense of a very different time. This site is one of two camping sites along the 2-3 day Walk into History hike.

mapList.access_desc:
The New Federal Mill can only be reached via foot from the Ada Tree Walk along Federal Road or from the Walk into History.
By Vehicle, take directions to the Ada Tree Picnic Area. Once there, walk along Federal Road (also disabled access to the Ada Tree) for approximately 1km. turn left, following signage to the New Federal Mill site. After 1km, you will reach the historical mill site. 
At this point, you can continue along the walk into history heading westward or head north for approximately 1.6km to continue to the Ada Tree, returning to the car park.  
From the western end, the New Federal Mill can be reached by walking east for 2.2km from the tramway crossroads on the Walk Into History, passing an impressive partially collapsed tramway bridge on-route.
mapList.name: Federal Mill Camping Area
mapList.comments: New Federal Mill dominated the sawmilling industry in the Warburton area for almost 15 years. Its closure in 1949 signalled the end of the timber tramway era.

mapList.access_desc: From Powelltown, head east along the Yarra Junction - Noojee Road (C425) for 6km then turn left up Big Creek Road. Travel along Big Creek Road for 22km and turn right down Federal Road. Travel along Federal Road for 3km until you reach the Ada Tree Picnic Area. From Warburton Travel along the Warburton - Woodspoint Road (C511) for 10km and Turn Right onto Brahams Road. Continue for 13km and veer left onto Big Creek Road. After 4km, turn right down Federal Road. Travel along Federal Road for 3km until you reach the Ada Tree Picnic Area. For Disabled Access: A key is available at the Powelltown shop for the disabled access track, which can be entered from the Ada Tree Picnic Area car park.
mapList.name: Ada Tree Picnic Area

mapList.access_desc: From Melbourne head out along the Maroondah Highway to Lilydale. Past Lilydale, head right onto Warburton Highway. Continue the extent of Warburton Highway, through the township of Warburton onto Woods Point Road. Continue until you reach the town of East Warburton where you will make a right hand turn onto Brahams Road. Further up Brahams Road you will find the Trail Bike Visitor Area on your right.\r\n
mapList.name: Brahams Trail Bike Visitor Area

mapList.access_desc: From Melbourne head east towards Noojee via the Yarra Valley in the east or Neerim in the south.  Once on the Mount Baw Baw Tourist Road, travel for approximately 2kms and then turn right where sign posted to enter the Noojee Trestle Bridge and Historic Features Reserve.  The bridge is located about 500m along a well-formed gravel road
mapList.name: Noojee Trestle Bridge
mapList.comments: See Victoria's tallest remaining trestle bridge in a beautiful tall forest setting. A popular site only 2km west of Noojee.  A great spot for a picnic, there is also a short 300m loop walk up and across the bridge, comprising a steep set of rocky stairs that take you up to the top of the trestle bridge. From here take in tall forest views as you walk across the historic wooden bridge high above the gully, returning down another set of steep stairs and onto a formed track to the carpark. A must do for those who enjoy the thrill of being up high!

mapList.access_desc: Head north on Bennett Street from the Noojee township across the bridge over the Latrobe River.  Take the left turn immediately after the bridge into McCarthy Spur Road.  Follow this road across a second bridge over the Loch River and the picnic ground is on your left.
mapList.name: Noojee Depot Picnic Area
mapList.comments: Located alongside the Latrobe River in Noojee, this site offers a tranquil setting for a picnic and an ideal base to fish. It is also the starting point for the historic Ralph Cornwall Tramway Walk.

mapList.access_desc: From Yarram take the Hyland Highway to the township of Won Wron and then travel 5km East on Napier Road to White Woman's Waterhole campsite. From Woodside continue West on the Carrajung-Woodside Rd after Duke St. After turning onto Napier Rd it is a further 5 minutes to the campground.
mapList.name: White Womans Waterhole
mapList.comments: **Please be aware this site will be closed on 23rd  25th of August 2019 for a private event**\r\nA great jumping off point to explore the Won Wron and Mullungdung State Forests. Campsites and picnic areas are available and a couple of short walks are situated nearby.

mapList.access_desc: Head north out of Noojee on the Loch Valley Road for approximately 8km, where you will find the sign-posted campground on the left a few hundred metres after the bitumen road turns to gravel.  Easy 2WD access.
mapList.name: Poplars Reserve
mapList.comments: An expansive, grassy site alongside the picturesque Loch River, dotted with well-established Poplar trees.  Only 10 minutes from Noojee, the Poplars Reserve is suited to campervanning, camping and picnicking.

mapList.close_reason: SITE CLOSED - Toorongo Falls Campground 1 will remain closed until Spring 2019 to allow refurbishment works to be finalised and resting of the site.
mapList.access_desc: Head east from Noojee on the Mount Baw Baw Tourist Road for approximately 2km and take a left turn into Toorongo Valley Road.  The site is accessed on the right after about 10km along this well-formed gravel road.
mapList.name: Toorongo Falls Site One
mapList.comments: An expansive drive-in hilly camping spot with easy access to the Toorongo River. Tall trees are dotted around on site with a background of bushy hills. Picnicking and open BBQ opportunities feature.

mapList.close_reason: SITE CLOSED - Toorongo Falls Campground 2 will remain closed until Spring 2019 to allow refurbishment works to be finalised and resting of the site.
mapList.access_desc: Head east from Noojee on the Mount Baw Baw Tourist Road for approximately 2km and take a left turn into Toorongo Valley Road.  The site is accessed about 10km along this well-formed gravel road via the Toorongo Falls Campsite One.
mapList.name: Toorongo Falls Site Two
mapList.comments: SITE CLOSED: Significant refurbishment occurring to campgrounds - site closed to camping until works are completed. Day visitor access to Picnic Area and Toorongo / Amphitheatre Falls Walking Tracks will remain open. Please visit nearby camping areas including Poplars Reserve or Checking Station -- A large, grassy and open spot on the banks of the Toorongo River, sitting against a great green backdrop of tall forest trees. Camping and picnicking opportunities feature.  Access is via Toorongo Falls Site One.

mapList.access_desc: Head east from Noojee on the Mount Baw Baw Tourist Road for approximately 2km and take a left turn into Toorongo Valley Road.  Site access is at the end of this 10km well formed gravel road.
mapList.name: Toorongo Falls Picnic Area

mapList.access_desc: Head north out of Noojee on the Loch Valley Road for approximately 8 km, then turn right into Toorongo Road and make your way through the plantation forests for a further 3 and half kms until you reach the junction with North Loch Road. Turn left into North Loch Road and the site will be immediately to your right.
mapList.name: Checking Station
mapList.comments: A great base for trailbike riders to explore the diverse range of surrounding tracks in the Noojee State Forest.  While primarily catering for trailbike riders, this site is also a pretty place for a picnic or camping.

mapList.access_desc: Turn off the Moe  Rawson Rd approximately 2 km south of Erica onto Telbit Rd, continue along this Rd, Tyers Junction Picnic area is accessed just after Morgans Mill Rd.
mapList.name: Tyers Junction Picnic Area

mapList.access_desc: Take Walhalla Rd south of Rawson, this is quite a winding road and can get busy on weekend, from there turn onto Cooper Creek Rd. Follow then turn left onto Coopers Creek Track, please do not continue along Coopers Creek Rd as it runs onto private property. \r\n\r\nContinue straight into the Coopers Creek recreation area as Coopers Creek Track swings right to cross the River, then the camp area one is reached by taking the first left, as you hit the day visitor area.
mapList.name: Coopers Creek Camping Area One
mapList.comments: Enjoy some time with family and friends in beautiful surrounds on the banks of the Thomson river just a stone throw from Walhalla and Erica. This area is rich with history and natural features ready to be explored, just up the road are the old Walhalla Rail Trail and historic Horseshoe Bend Tunnel.

mapList.access_desc: Take Walhalla Rd south of Rawson, this is quite a winding road and can get busy on weekend, from there turn onto Cooper Creek Rd. Follow then turn left onto Coopers Creek Track, please do not continue along Coopers Creek Rd as it runs onto private property. \r\n\r\nContinue straight into the Coopers Creek recreation area as Coopers Creek Trk swings right to cross the River, picnic area one is on the right by the River.
mapList.name: Coopers Creek Day Visitor Area One
mapList.comments: Enjoy some time with family and friends in beautiful surrounds on the banks of the Thomson river just a stone throw from Walhalla and Erica. This area is rich with history and natural features ready to be explored, just up the road are the old Walhalla Rail Trail and historic Horseshoe Bend Tunnel.

mapList.access_desc: Follow directions to Coopers Creek picnic area one, continue straight passed picnic area 1 and overnight camp areas 1 and 2 and you will reach picnic area 2 shortly after.
mapList.name: Coopers Creek Day Visitor Area Two
mapList.comments: Enjoy some time with family and friends in beautiful surrounds on the banks of the Thomson river just a stone throw from Walhalla and Erica. This area is rich with history and natural features ready to be explored, just up the road are the old Walhalla Rail Trail and historic Horseshoe Bend Tunnel.

mapList.access_desc: Follow the directions to the Cooper Creek camping area one, continue straight passed picnic and camp area one, camp area two will be well signposted on your left.
mapList.name: Coopers Creek Camping Area Two
mapList.comments: Enjoy some time with family and friends in beautiful surrounds on the banks of the Thomson river just a stone throw from Walhalla and Erica.
